Today, even though this ruling is only binding in the 6th Circuit, major email providers (Google, Microsoft, and more) have said that they abide by the “Warshak standard,” in that they now require a warrant to give up email.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_v._Warshak …

We have Judge Keith to thank.

1122837699516411904.text:
"Such a practice is no more than back-door wiretapping. I doubt that such actions, if contested directly in court, would withstand the muster of the Fourth Amendment. Email, much like telephone, provides individuals with a means to communicate in private.”

Pg 141 of my book:pic.twitter.com/BiZS9GBWhX

1122837377188270080.text:
Judge Keith wrote a separate opinion, agreeing with the majority.

https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3924349-6C-opinion-US-v-Warshak.html#document/p97/a368172 …

As he wrote:

"In practice, the government used the statute as a means to monitor Warshak after the investigation started without his knowledge and without a warrant."

1122836811766693893.text:
Over the course of that case, the government was able to obtain Warshak’s emails under 18 U.S.C. § 2703(f)—a subpoena, not a warrant. Warshak’s lawyers didn’t find this out until two years after it had happened. 

Basically, DOJ had used Warshak’s email provider against him.

1122836042221006849.text: In 2010, at the age of 87, Judge Keith was part of a key ruling in an email privacy case called US v. Warshak. (The defendant was Steven Warshak, the man behind a company that sold supplements for "male enhancement.”)

1122835093943353344.text: In 1977, President Carter appointed Judge Keith to the 6th Circuit.

1122834581403721730.text:
The opinion: https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/407/297 …

The audio of oral arguments: https://www.oyez.org/cases/1971/70-153 …

1122834431918649345.text: In other words, the Nixon-era Executive Branch (DOJ, FBI, etc), and all future executive branches, could not wiretap an American, in America, simply by invoking "national security.”

1122834024462979072.text:
Eventually, SCOTUS ruled 8-0 in favor of Judge Keith. 

"These Fourth Amendment freedoms cannot properly be guaranteed if domestic security surveillances may be conducted solely within the discretion of the Executive Branch."

1122833074394411009.text:
Cert was granted on June 21, 1971.

Justice Rehnquist, a new appointee, recused himself from the case, as he had worked on the DOJ briefs in the case, having come from the OLC.

(Source: https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3766850-The-Story-of-United-States-v-United-States.html#document/p18/a497425 …)

1122832586454241280.text:
The 6th Circuit denied the DOJ’s appeal—which was also based on the All Writs Act—in a 2-1 ruling. 

DOJ appealed to the Supreme Court.

1122831814769483776.text: The government asked the 6th Circuit to issue a a writ of mandamus against Judge Keith himself, attempting to force him to "release the surveillance tapes of the Sinclair defendants that he had impounded.”https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3766851-200311-Court-Legacy.html#document/p5/a497424 …

1122831654551216135.text: DOJ didn’t like this opinion, and appealed to the 6th US Circuit Court of Appeals.

1122830599121772545.text: “The position of the Attorney General is untenable. It is supported neither historically, nor by the language of the Omnibus Crime Act. Such power held by one individual was never contemplated by the framers of our Constitution and cannot be tolerated today."

1122830523641020417.text:
…

"In this turbulent time of unrest, it is often difficult for the established and contented members of our society to tolerate, much less try to understand, the contemporary challenges to our existing form of government."

1122830225501507584.text: "We are, after all, dealing not with the rights of one individual defendant, but, rather, we are here concerned with the possible infringement of a fundamental freedom guaranteed to all American citizens.”

1122829997075566593.text:
As Judge Keith wrote, granting the motion to disclose government surveillance (https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp/321/1074/2597112/ …) :

"The contention by the Government that in cases involving 'national security' a warrantless search is not an illegal one, must be cautiously approached and analyzed."

1122829602114682880.text:
DOJ put forward a theory, which came to be known as the Mitchell Doctrine, which basically found that the government could wiretap anyone in the name of national security.

Judge Keith wasn’t buying it.

1122828544307023874.text: "Plamondon has participated in conversations which were overheard by government agents who were monitoring wiretaps which were being employed tot gather intelligence information deemed necessary to protect the nation from attempts of domestic organizations to attack…government."

1122828196595097600.text:
As the case moved along, by Oct 1970, defense attorneys filed a motion for the disclosure of electronic surveillance.

When DOJ officials checked with Main Justice, AG John Mitchell filed a sworn affidavit in which he said that Plamondon was heard on a wiretap.

1122827332715200515.text:

"We are a bunch of arrogant motherfuckers and we don't give a damn for any cop or any
phony-ass authority control-addict creeps who want to put us down.”

(Source: https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3766851-200311-Court-Legacy.html#document/p3/a497423 …)

1122827128305795072.text: The defendants in the case were three men— John Sinclair, Laurence "Pun" Plamondon, and John "Jack” Forest—who declared themselves as being part of the "White Panthers,” allied with the Black Panthers.

1122826083718586373.text:
By that point, Judge Keith had been a US District Judge for the Eastern District of Michigan—appointed by LBJ—for roughly 2 years.

He was only one of a handful of African-American judges on the federal bench. He was only 35 when he was nominated to the bench.

1122825393789186050.text:
This case began when a CIA recruiting office in Ann Arbor, MI was bombed on September 29, 1968. No one was injured.

By Oct 1969 a grand jury returned an indictment against three men.
